page.title: 17THE COTTON WOOL MILL
page.content: There is a cotton wool mill beside the River Caldew at the edge of Buckabank. The first mill was built in 1793, but this was destroyed by lightning in 1901. This is one of the few mills in Great Britain that produces pure cotton wool. Its product is used as padding in clothes and coffins, and in filters or dust masks, particularly those used by miners. The mill was water driven until 1972: its wheel was one of the biggest steel water wheels working in Britain. In 1972, the mill was converted to run on electricity. The Mill employs forty-two people, very few when compared with the three hundred people who worked there in the Eighteenth Century.
